abstract.p: Gov Christine Whitman of New Jersey signs law permitting federal program that allows states to continue Medicaid benefits to people with recognized disabilities who earn up to 250 percent of federal poverty level (S)

block.p: More people with disabilities who enter the workplace will be able hold on to their Medicaid benefits, under a law signed by Governor Whitman last week. States and the federal government share the cost of Medicaid, and the New Jersey measure is permitted under a federal program that lets states grant continued benefits to people who work in wheelchairs, on Braille-encoded keyboards or with any recognized disability and earn up to 250 percent of the federal poverty level. Without the measure, disabled people whose incomes exceed the poverty level, which is $8,350 for an individual and $11,250 for couples, lose their Medicaid benefits.
